message_1: How many ways are there to distribute 10 identical candies among 4 different children if each child must receive at least 2 candies?
message_2:
Since each of the 4 children must receive at least 2 candies, we will first give 2 candies to each child. Now we have 2 candies left to distribute among the 4 children.

We can use the stars and bars method to solve this problem. We have 2 candies (stars) and 3 dividers (bars) to separate the candies among the 4 children. We need to arrange these 5 objects (2 stars and 3 bars).

The number of ways to arrange these objects is the number of combinations of choosing 2 positions for the stars out of the 5 available positions (the remaining positions will be occupied by the bars).

Using the combination formula, we have:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

C(5, 2) = 5! / (2!(5-2)!)
C(5, 2) = 5! / (2!3!)
C(5, 2) = (5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1) / ((2 × 1)(3 × 2 × 1))
C(5, 2) = 120 / (2 × 6)
C(5, 2) = 120 / 12
C(5, 2) = 10

So there are 10 ways to distribute the remaining 2 candies among the 4 children, given that each child already has at least 2 candies.
